That would have been in the Transvaal, Orange Free State and Northern Natal.

In the BRL it consists of cells and it operated underground.

Was it said that there would have been any actions?
And what would happen in the nature of the action?
It would depend.  We had to get weapons and we had to prepare for a full scale war.
Now the weapons that you had to obtain, for whom did you have to obtain it?
Where would you have obtained it?
We had to get it from any available source.
Now would it be on a legal or illegal way?
If it had to be with violence, it would have been done in that way, otherwise without any violence.
Was the BWB aware of the fact that you had training and that you had knowledge of the airforce base at Devon?
Yes they were aware of it.
And that was also where you received part of your training?
Did you at any stage receive a call from anyone?
Do you know who the person was?
A person told me that the time is now appropriate to get weapons and I should know where to get them.

The choice of the target was left to me.

Initially I would have acted with my personal member but at that stage he was not available.
Now your personal member, who was that?
That would have been General Gerhard van Rensburg.

Now I contacted ...[inaudible] van Schalkwyk of the AWB, a close confidante of mine and I asked him whether Mr Holder and Van Zyl would assist me with this operation.

He told me that when I met them I could trust them and that they would be prepared to assist me with any operation if I needed people and he also told me that I could trust them.

They always talked about it that they wanted to obtain weapons but they never really did anything.
On the 23rd April 1994 did you do any planning?
Everything happened very fast, I really didn't have time to thoroughly do preparation.
Mr Holder and Van Zyl picked me up at the single quarters.
Was it on your request or theirs?
It was on my request and from there we went through to Pretoria.  We had a look at the situation Vermeulen Street, there were certain guards at a building, I don't know which building.
It is in Vermeulen Street in Pretoria.
Now this particular building, was there any mention made of it in the BWB discussions?
No not really, I passed it and I then saw that there were any guards.
Were you accompanied at that opportunity?
Yes I was, by Gerhard van Rensburg.

That was to look at the situation in Vermeulen Street to see whether we could get the weapons from these guys.
Now this is not from a safe, it is from the person himself?
And after you had a look did you think you could act there?
No at that stage there were more guards than were expected and I did not want to expose my people to the risk.
So there was nothing done that day?
And what did you do then?

Then we went back to Secunda and on the way I remembered Devon Airforce Base, it was on our way and I then informed Mr Holder and Van Zyl about this and then told them that at the guard gate there are usually two airforce troops, usually they are weaponed with R5 and also 9 mm pistols.

And we then decided to try and take off these weapons from the guards.  Mr Holder and myself, we put on airforce uniforms along the road and we travelled a bit further and just past the base, we stopped, we got out of the car, we went into the base.
At that stage you still believed that that base was still operating as an airforce base?

Mr Holder and myself then went to the guard room, that is at the gate.  I walked in first and when I walked in I saw that there were police.  I didn't expect police there.  I then aimed my weapon at the guards and I told them they shouldn't be Rambos, we're from a right-wing organisation, we only want their weapons.  The guard nearest to me smiled at me as if he was thinking I was making a joke and then I ordered him to take out his weapon.  He took out his weapon and he lifted it.  I grabbed it with my left hand and in the meantime Mr Holder passed me, to the other guard, and that was Mr Swart I found out later on and whilst I held Mr Terblanche's weapon with my left arm, a shot went off. 	Mr Terblanche started struggling to get his weapon back and a shot was fired from my pistol.  Mr Terblanche took his weapon and I shot.  Mr Terblanche fell, I took his pistol and Mr Holder and myself left the scene.

It was to take the weapons from the guards.

That was to use it for the war.

Well the one part would have gone to the BWB and the others would have gone to the AWB.

No at that stage I didn't really know where I aimed my pistol, I just realised that I had to shoot.
Did you realise that there could be a possibility that you could kill him?
Did you at that stage in any way act for your own gain, did you have any revenge feelings, did you know the person?

They were part of the government.
And in the BWB itself, did there exist any system according to which when BWB members acted a message would be sent out so that you could act.

Well when a cell operated in the BRL they were provided with a telephone number for contact purposes and to say that cell number so and so had accepted responsibility for the deed that had been committed.
Now after this action, did you feel that there was something wrong with your hand?  What was wrong?
Well I didn't realise at that stage what was wrong.  Only in the car on the way back to Secunda I realised that I had been wounded in the left arm.
Okay, the person had been shot, you'd taken the firearm and you had left the building, you and Mr Holder?
Well we went to the car which had been waiting for us.
Who was waiting in the car?
Is it one of the two applicants on the left?

We returned to Secunda.  I requested that they drop me off along the Main Road leading into Secunda because my General lived directly next to the Main Road.  I crossed the wire fence to Mr van Rensburg and he nursed my wound.
Are you referring to Mr van Rensburg, your fellow cell member, Mr Gerhard van Rensburg?

And as a member of the AWB he took me to this person and in the meanwhile the BWB headquarters in Rustenburg had been approached by him to find out whether there was a doctor who was supporting our cause.  In the meanwhile I returned to a doctor and he took me to the member where the doctor treated me.

How long were you in hospital?

Yes they were aware of what we'd done there.

No, I didn't do so personally but my General did so.
Did you inform your General, Gerhard van Rensburg about what had happened?
And as far as you know was this carried over or was this message given through to the movement?
Did you have any opportunity to accept responsibility for this deed?
At that stage I couldn't accept responsibility for the deed because shortly after my hospitalisation I was arrested.
Did you state your version of what had happened to the police?
And did you also inform them that you had initially gone to Pretoria?
So they were aware of this throughout?
And you also made a statement before a Magistrate?
And during your trial did you initially plead not guilty?
Was that before Judge Grobbelaar in the Circuit Court of Springs?
Yes that is correct to both questions.

Without having been cross-examined at that stage?
Why did you initially plead not guilty?
That was at the recommendation of my Advocate, Mr Nel.
Did you plead not guilty to both the murder and the robbery with aggravating circumstances?
And you were found guilty on both counts?

Mr Chair, I wish to just state that I am in possession of Judge Grobbelaar's finding in the case and I will provide the Honourable Committee with copies of this, I obtained this yesterday.  If I look at the finding the judgement, page 2, approximately line 20, says statement had been submitted, that the respective cases of the State and the Defence had been concluded and both passed that the accused be found guilty and then Judge Grobbelaar said it was clear that you had been of the intention to plead guilty, is that correct?
After this deed and after these events and that which you had been wanting to achieve, how do you feel about all of this?
Well I'm disappointed because I feel that I had not really achieved my objective.
And how doe you feel about the victim, the late Mr Terblanche who was fatally wounded and killed during this action?
Well I'm very sorry about the death of Mr Terblanche.
During your trial did you meet any relative of Mr Terblanche?
Yes, during the trial I met his father and his stepbrother and other relatives.
Did you discuss things with them?
Yes they three talked to me but in particular Mr Terblanche, the deceased's father.
What did you say to him?

Well just after deciding to change my plea from not guilty to guilty, Mr Terblanche after the court had adjourned, met me in the passage and he held me against him and said they didn't hold it against me and they were praying for me and also on the day I was sentenced, after my sentence had been given, I was given time to greet my family and when I stepped towards my family, Mr Terblanche met me, gave me Christian books, told me that they didn't hold it against me, that they realised it had been for a political struggle and they were praying for me.
Did you at any stage receive any letter from anybody in this regard?

Well after I had been sentenced, Mr Terblanche wrote a letter to me whilst I was in prison in which he explained to me how he had felt in the beginning about the death of his son and that he had realised after he had met me that he had to forgive me and there he once again confirmed that he had forgiven me and that they didn't hold it against me.
Today, do you commit yourself to violence, to negotiation or what is your position at present?
Well at this stage today I do not wish to associate myself with violence, I feel negotiation is the right road to follow.

Just a moment, your Honour.

Yes, I did not do it for any other purpose or any other objective than a political objective.

Well I definitely don't agree with that because I can't see how I could have shot myself because if one looks at the degrees at which the projectile had penetrated my arm and if one looks at the course between the entry wound and exit wound it's impossible that I could have shot myself because the firearm would have been aimed at myself which is not something I would have done.

Mr van Zyl says that he looked at the pistol that had been taken in the robbery after Mr Holder had received it and had later been handed over to Van Zyl.  Van Zyl said that he checked the firearm and it was apparent that Mr Terblanche's pistol had never been cocked or fired that night.
Well I was aware that it had not been fired, I was aware of that but as I said I had the barrel in my left hand and not for a moment did I think that Mr Terblanche had fired any of the shots.
